title: Business Trip Hotel
description: You're staying at a hotel for a business conference. The Wi-Fi situation is confusing, and you have important work to do before tomorrow's presentation.

scenes.title: Checking In
scenes.description: You've just arrived at the Grand Metropolitan Hotel after a long flight. Tomorrow's presentation is crucial, and you need to review some documents and respond to emails tonight. The room has a desk and you're ready to work.

scenes.title: Hotel Wi-Fi Options
scenes.description: Your laptop shows several networks. The hotel information card on the desk mentions 'complimentary Wi-Fi' but the network name is partially obscured by a coffee stain.

networks.description: Open network - typical for hotels with portal login
Secured premium network - may require purchase
Conference center network - may not be for guests

actions.label: Call front desk to verify network

scenes.title: Captive Portal
scenes.description: A login page appears. It asks for your room number and last name to authenticate. There's also a checkbox to 'Install our HotelConnect app for the best experience.'

actions.label: Go back and try a different network

scenes.title: Verified Information
scenes.description: The front desk confirms: 'Our free Wi-Fi is GrandMetro_Guest - you'll need your room number and last name to log in. We also have GrandMetro_Premium for $15/night with faster speeds and better security.'

scenes.title: Premium Network
scenes.description: The premium network requires a password. The hotel information card shows it costs $15/night but promises 'enterprise-grade security.'

task.title: Premium Network Decision
task.description: Decide whether to pay for the premium network or use the free option.

scenes.title: Premium Connection
scenes.description: You're connected to the premium network...

consequence.title: Secure Choice
consequence.whatHappened: You chose the premium, password-protected network. This provides WPA2 encryption between your device and the access point, meaning other hotel guests cannot eavesdrop on your traffic.
consequence.whyRisky: This is a much safer choice than the open network. Here's why it matters: on the free open network, any guest with basic tools could capture your traffic. The premium network's password creates unique encryption keys for your session. The $15 investment is worthwhile when you're handling business data. The only remaining risk is that the hotel's network administrators could theoretically see your traffic, but reputable hotels don't monitor guest activity.
consequence.saferAlternative: For maximum protection, use a VPN even on the premium network. But your choice was solid - you recognized that network security has real value, especially when doing business work.
consequence.technicalExplanation: WPA2 uses the shared password to derive unique encryption keys for each connected device through a four-way handshake. Unlike open networks where packets fly through the air in readable form, your data is scrambled in a way that other guests cannot decode, even though they know the same password.

scenes.title: Fake Hotel Network
scenes.description: You connected to what you thought was the hotel's network...

consequence.title: Evil Twin Attack
consequence.whatHappened: You connected to 'GrandMetro-Guest' - notice the hyphen instead of the underscore? This subtle difference means you joined a fake network, probably set up by someone in a nearby room or even in the parking lot. A fake login portal captured your room number, name, and any passwords you entered.
consequence.whyRisky: Hotels are prime hunting grounds for attackers because business travelers often carry valuable corporate data and are tired from travel, making them less vigilant. The attacker deliberately chose a name almost identical to the real network - 'GrandMetro-Guest' versus 'GrandMetro_Guest' - knowing that exhausted travelers glance at network names rather than reading them carefully. Once connected, everything you do online passes through the attacker's equipment. They can read unencrypted traffic, capture login credentials from fake portals, and even modify web pages you're viewing.
consequence.saferAlternative: Always verify the exact network name with hotel staff - don't assume. Look for subtle differences in capitalization, punctuation, or spelling. When tired from travel, that's precisely when you should be most careful, not less.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Evil twin attacks are especially effective in hotels because guests expect to see multiple similar-sounding networks. The attacker's equipment acts as a man-in-the-middle, potentially stripping HTTPS encryption or presenting convincing fake login pages. Your room number and name are now linked to your browsing activity.

cascadingEffects.effect: Fake portal captured your name and room number
Attacker links your identity to browsing activity
Corporate data from email becomes accessible
Business secrets or client info may be compromised

scenes.title: App Installation Request
scenes.description: You installed the app the portal suggested...

consequence.title: Potentially Malicious App
consequence.whatHappened: You installed an app directly from a login portal instead of from the official app store. Even if this was truly the hotel's app, you've bypassed all the security checks that app stores perform.
consequence.whyRisky: This is one of the most dangerous things you can do on a network. Here's why: Legitimate businesses almost never require app installation just to use Wi-Fi. When an app is downloaded from a captive portal instead of an app store, there's no review process checking for malware. The app could request permissions to read your emails, access your files, track your location, record audio, or even capture everything you type. Some malicious apps install hidden 'MDM profiles' that give remote attackers persistent access to your device even after you delete the visible app. The convenience of 'faster connection' is never worth this risk.
consequence.saferAlternative: Never install apps, profiles, or certificates from captive portals. If a business legitimately has an app you want, search for it in your device's official app store. If it's not there, that's a red flag.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Sideloaded apps bypass app store security scanning. Mobile Device Management (MDM) profiles can grant extensive device control - reading encrypted messages, installing other apps silently, and persisting across factory resets. Corporate espionage groups specifically target business travelers with these attacks.

cascadingEffects.effect: App reads your contacts, emails, and files
Your location is tracked in real-time
Credentials are captured and sold or used

task.riskHint: Downloaded files could be intercepted or modified on insecure networks.

scenes.title: Presentation Files
scenes.description: Your VPN is active. You need to download an updated presentation file.

task.title: Download Updated Slides
task.description: Download the updated presentation from the cloud sharing link.

scenes.title: Unprotected Download
scenes.description: You downloaded the file on the open network...

consequence.title: Risky File Transfer
consequence.whatHappened: You downloaded work files on an open hotel network without VPN protection. While modern cloud services use HTTPS, you've exposed metadata about your business activities and potentially the files themselves.
consequence.whyRisky: Here's the real concern: hotel networks are shared by dozens or hundreds of guests, some of whom may have malicious intent. On an open network, a sophisticated attacker could potentially intercept your download link, redirect you to a modified file, or at minimum log that you're downloading sensitive business documents from your company's cloud storage. The metadata alone - which company you work for, what cloud services you use, when you're active - has value to corporate spies. For a presentation that might contain pricing, strategy, or client information, this exposure matters.
consequence.saferAlternative: Always use a VPN when downloading work files on hotel networks. The few seconds it takes to connect could prevent a data breach. For truly sensitive files, consider using mobile data or waiting for a trusted network.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Open hotel networks transmit data unencrypted between your device and the router. While HTTPS protects file contents in transit, DNS queries reveal which services you're using, and sophisticated attacks can attempt to inject malicious content into downloads through techniques like SSL stripping or malicious proxy configurations.

scenes.title: Protected Download
scenes.description: You downloaded the file with VPN protection...

consequence.title: Secure File Transfer
consequence.whatHappened: You used VPN protection while downloading your work files. All traffic was encrypted through a secure tunnel, protecting both the files and all metadata about your business activities from anyone on the hotel network.
consequence.whyRisky: You made the right choice. The VPN means that anyone monitoring the hotel network - whether a malicious guest or even a compromised hotel system - sees only encrypted traffic going to a VPN server. They can't tell what you're downloading, where it's from, or what company you work for. Your business remains your business.
consequence.saferAlternative: This was excellent practice. For extremely confidential files, some organizations require file integrity verification through checksums - your IT department may have guidelines for this.
consequence.technicalExplanation: The VPN encrypted all traffic before it left your device, wrapping your cloud download in an additional layer of protection. The hotel network sees only encrypted packets going to a VPN IP, with no visibility into the actual destination, content, or metadata of your file transfer.

scenes.title: Using Business Center
scenes.description: You decided to use the hotel's business center...

consequence.title: Cautious Choice
consequence.whatHappened: You chose to use the hotel's business center for this download. Business centers typically have wired connections, which are harder to eavesdrop on than wireless networks.
consequence.whyRisky: This was a security-conscious decision. Wired connections can't be intercepted by nearby wireless attackers. However, remember: if using the business center's computers rather than your own laptop, those shared machines could have keyloggers or malware from previous users. Always bring your own device when possible, and log out of all accounts when finished.
consequence.saferAlternative: The ideal approach: use your own laptop with a VPN on the business center's wired connection. This gives you the security of a wired connection plus the encryption of a VPN, while avoiding the risks of shared computers.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Wired ethernet connections require physical access to intercept, unlike Wi-Fi which broadcasts through walls. However, wired connections still route through the hotel's network infrastructure, so a VPN remains valuable. Shared computers pose different risks - malware, keyloggers, and stored credentials from previous users.

scenes.title: Scenario Complete
scenes.description: You've completed the Hotel Business Trip scenario! Let's see how well you navigated the hotel's network challenges.
